awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  A Fresh Look at M Dwarf Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Over 70% of all stars are “M dwarfs”, which are much smaller, cooler, and less luminous than the Sun. A better understanding of their physical properties touches on galactic chemical evolution, the dynamics of the galaxy, stellar atmospheres, molecular astrophysics, star formation, planet formation, and exoplanet characterization.  This group will advance our understanding by uniting the best physical models of stellar interiors and atmospheres and testing them with high-quality observations. These projects have an important training component, as much of the work will be done by graduate students at UC Santa Cruz, Arizona State University, and Boston University. Undergraduate students will also be involved in the research, and the team will create a new curriculum and training materials, including a webinar for students to learn about future careers. 

The team will carry out a thorough modeling study of M dwarf atmospheres, interiors, and evolution. Previous work on M dwarf physics has used methods and codes devised for more massive stars, with workers moving down in mass to M dwarfs. This group will use modeling tools developed for brown dwarfs, just lower in mass than the M stars, and then move up in mass to model these objects. M dwarfs and brown dwarfs share many properties, like molecule-dominated atmospheres and partially degenerate interiors.  This team will use spectral "retrieval" models for M stars, a fully Bayesian data-driven method, to yield best-fit temperature structures and abundances that are not bound to pre-computed atmosphere grids.  They will focus on benchmark, well-studied M stars in orbit around Sun-like primaries.  Based on the outcomes of this work, they will then compute a large grid of radiative-convective model atmospheres to yield trends in temperature, gravity, and metallicity, which will be of use to the entire astronomical community. Such models will also serve as the upper boundary conditions for new self-consistent M dwarf evolution models with MESA, which will include a new hydrogen equation of state. This will allow them to pursue detailed comparisons with previous theoretical and observational work on M dwarf atmospheres, their locations on the H-R diagram, and observed mass-radius relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
M dwarf stars are the most common type of stars in our galaxy, making up about 70-80% of the stars in our cosmic neighborhood. These stars are smaller and cooler than our Sun, with temperatures ranging from 2500K to 4000K. Due to their abundance and longevity, they are key to understanding planetary systems and the evolution of galaxies. They also frequently host rocky, Earth-like planets, making them prime targets for studying potentially habitable exoplanets.

Despite their importance, M dwarfs present a challenge for astronomers. Standard stellar models, originally designed for Sun-like stars, struggle to accurately describe the atmospheres of these cooler stars. This is because M dwarfs have atmospheres rich in molecules like water vapor, carbon monoxide, and titanium oxide, which create complex spectral features that are difficult to model. Additionally, processes like convection (the movement of heat within the star) and magnetic activity (such as starspots) further complicate accurate characterization.

To address these challenges, our research introduced SPHINX, a new grid of stellar atmosphere models specifically designed for M dwarfs. SPHINX uses cutting-edge computational methods to simulate the atmospheres of these stars, incorporating the latest molecular data and physical processes to improve accuracy. In our work we aimed to:

Improving Stellar Property Estimates: We used SPHINX to analyze spectra (the light fingerprint of stars) and derive fundamental properties like temperature, gravity, metallicity (chemical composition), and carbon-to-oxygen ratios.

Validating the Model: We tested SPHINX on two key sets of M dwarfs:
Binary Star Systems- M dwarfs paired with Sun-like stars, where we could compare our results with well-known measurements of their companions, and  Interferometric Measurements-M dwarfs whose sizes were directly measured using precise telescope techniques.

More Accurate Measurements: Our model provided more consistent and accurate estimates of these stars' properties compared to previous models, significantly improving our understanding of M dwarf atmospheres.

Understanding the atmospheres of M dwarfs is critical for exoplanet research. Many of the planets being studied by the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) orbit M dwarfs, and to correctly interpret their atmospheres, we must first understand the properties of their host stars.

Our research directly contributes to improving models used in exoplanet atmosphere studies, helping to refine our search for potentially habitable worlds. By providing more accurate measurements of M dwarfs, we ensure that planetary properties—like temperature, chemical composition, and atmospheric conditions—are not biased by incorrect assumptions about their host stars.

This work is a significant step forward in stellar astrophysics and planetary science, providing the tools needed to unlock new discoveries in our search for life beyond Earth.
